review_title: A small fish in a really big pond
pros:
- Education benefits are the main plus for working at Pitt. Was able to complete my masters with a 20-25% out of pocket cost
- Medical and retirement are great. However, whats the use of a high retirement matching or excellent medical benefits if the salary for employees is pathetic?
- Working from home options
cons:
- As stated earlier, the pay/salary is absolutely pathetic. At the acceptance of my full time staff position, I was told of all the amazing ways to grow and move "up the ladder" at the university. What a joke. In my 3+ years at Pitt, I received a $.50 raise. You read that right. Not $.50 per year. $.50 total, over 3 years...
- Absolutely no room for growth... unless you are a favored employee. As I stated earlier, I worked at the university for over 3 years, and not once was I approached for promotional opportunities, additional duties, etc. 
- Be wary of the "additional duties" section of your JD, because you are in for a ride. When you read the "additional duties as required" portion of your JD, please run screaming. There were many instances (and some long-term situations as well) where I took on duties that were nowhere to be found in my job duties, that were made permanent to my position, with no extra pay I may add. Due to the short staffed nature of Pitt, as well as some truly lazy and incompetent workers, those that show some form of hard work will be rewarded with other peoples work at no extra pay to the employee.
- Hypermanagement- Love having your work overman-aged and overanalyzed? Love being told what to do all of the time, with no individualization or process improvement? Then this is the place for you.
- Don't even think about promotions. Just don't. You may ask, but it will only fall on deaf ears.

pros: Great benefits including medical, bus pass, access to gym facilities. Leadership was very flexible with mid-day appointments. Lunch break was flexible. Found a great sense of community among coworkers and department efforts to build comradery. The time off during December (~ 2 weeks) is a huge perk that allowed for travelling etc.
cons: Depending on the department there's not much room for growth. This also depends on the position you're in. For a world-class research university and a college among many others in the regions, the pay is comparatively low.

review_title: Only worth it for the education benefits
pros: Benefits are really good. There is an option for $0 premium health insurance and the education benefits are really good if you’re looking to get another degree. If you’re working full time, they’ll pay for about 90% of graduate studies and 97% of undergraduate studies. If you take that into consideration, it’s worth it in my opinion. Otherwise, if you’re not getting a degree, it’s better to just get a different higher paying job.
cons:
First off, it’s absolutely impossible to get an internal promotion. I was working under the title and pay if a research assistant but was actually doing the job of a research coordinator, which paid $10k more. I then found out after leaving that my coworker who did the exact same job as I did was making $10k more than I was. I was told for over a year that the promotion was “in progress” but never saw anything so I finally left. In that time of waiting for my promotion, three other people had been hired under a coordinator position while I was doing the same job and working as a research assistant. I had been there for almost 5 years and new hires were making more than I was because of how hard it was to be promoted internally. 

The pay is atrocious. With a master’s degree and over 5 years of working there, I was making $17/hr. I got another degree, had received exceptional reviews each year, and had taken on the responsibilities of the next level of employer without ever seeing a cent raise.

review_title: Good place to work - if you get into the right department.
pros: Great medical benefits, fairly affordable. Two weeks vacation, about two weeks sick time. Increased vacation at five years service.  Bonus week off between Christmas Eve and New Years, 6+ other paid holidays. Tuition benefits are excellent for self, spouse, domestic partners and children. Domestic partnership benefits available.  For Univ of Pittsburgh (NOT upmc employees) your staff ID gets you free fare on all Port Authority buses, trolleys, etc.
cons:
Make sure you do not compromise on your salary for your initial hire! You most likely will NEVER see more than a 4% raise unless you switch to another department and even then there are regulations limiting salary increase and regulating lateral moves. There are a lot of great places to work here but there are also a lot of crappy places to work here. Pay attention to the appearance and attitude of potential managers and co-workers during the interview. I absolutely love my current job and plan to stay for quite some time... but in my 6 years at Pitt I have worked in some absolutely horrid atmospheres. 

Even for equivalent job duties, your best chance at highest pay is in the medical and athletic departments. I make almost 30% more in a medical dept than I did in an arts dept doing pretty much the same thing.

Pitt is probably one of the best Universities in the country when it comes to making the best out of what they have, even with limited funds compared to bigger/private universities. Pitt truly is Pittsburgh's University: tough, gritty, diverse, hard working, and punching above their weight class.
cons: Certainly uneven experiences across the University. I've been blessed to work with a supervisor who has encouraged and found opportunities for me to growth personally and professionally. In an age where everyone seems to be working from home with three weeks of vacation, the lack of these benefits can be painful. These cons obviously lead to some major retention issues.

pros:
A research associate is given opportunities to grow academically in their career. The position is normally year to year and requires a PhD, but a Masters level degree can be used if the supervisor really wants to add you to the team. 

Graduate school is provided up to $5000, but you are taxed on that amount. 

You have many of the same privileges as faculty. 

Salary can range from $90,000 to $110,000.
cons:
Once the year to year contract is over, you get nothing.  No benefits, no insurance, nothing. This is not critical if you only have 1 or 2 years invested, but if you put in 20 years as a Research Associate be very careful to find other employment before your contact expires.

Once you pay is set it will not change!

You serve at the whim of the supervisor, if the supervisor decides to terminate your contract,  you have no ability to get it extended. Staff have more protections in place.

You will have a salary cap of $115,000. Sounds like a lot, but remember your job is to develop new ideas or acquire projects that make the University a lot of money. You would receive a lot more in a for profit business. Many of my projects were multi-million dollar projects. If you do not create new ideas or bring in large sums of money, you will be let go very quickly.

review_title: Great Opportunities, but not Family Friendly for new hires
pros: Pitt offers great healthcare, retirement, and education benefits, and the work can be really meaningful and important.
cons: Pitt has a long way to go to be a Family Friendly Workplace.  New staff start with zero sick days and vacation days, and two personal days that must be approved for use in advance by a supervisor and also used or lost within the fiscal year. It is not possible to work remotely until after the provisional period ends. For some that will be 3 months, and for many it will be 6 months. If an employee or his/her child gets sick for longer than 3 days within the first 30 days of employment, a new hire has few options other than having his or her pay docked once the small amount of sick time accrued and personal days run out.

job_title: Research Assistant II in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
Benefits are great: 
-Education benefit gives 90% off up to 6 credits of graduate school classes. That does change a fair amount once you've passed their allocated tax free limit as it gets charged at around 35%, meaning you might pay 2,000 dollars in taxes for what would be a 600 dollar semester post benefit. 
-Generous health care and dental. Health care plan goes through UPMC
-Retirement benefits are up to 8% matching 100% with vesting at 3 years.

This depends entirely on the lab you are with but in my case the lab gives me extremely interesting work I'm passionate about with plenty of freedom and flexibility in what to work on and when to work on it.
cons:
The pay is probably not as good as can be offered in industry. 
The conditions of the job are pretty much entirely up to the specific lab you work in so it's hard to predict what the culture and expectation will be like if you're not already acquainted with the group.

As is true in pretty much all of academia it can be hard to fully put the work down when you leave the workplace. Again, this varies by lab but it's very common for people to do extra things from home or on weekends if they feel it will help their group or advance their project.

pros: Good Environment. People are really nice here. Use cutting-edge technology.
cons: The salary is quite low.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Both the academics and city are great
cons: I can't think of any

pros: It is simple and nice.
cons: It is a little bit time consuming

pros: Diverse, laid back, positive atmosphere
cons: Lacks a bit of structure

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Good health insurance, Large pool of faculty
cons: Parking is hard to find around campus

pros: The benefits package is great
cons: The salary is less for comparable jobs

pros: Time off benefits was good
cons: Hours We’re not that great

review_title: I worked PT for several years while attending school. I transitioned from a temp to a regular employee.
pros: The work/life balance was very appealing, but I had a wonderful supervisor so that may not be the case across the board.  The tuition reimbursement is a great offset to the low pay, especially if you desire to take classes. It seemed to be fairly easy to advance and/or make lateral moves in my department. Obtaining regular employment via becoming a temporary employee (they have a temp office) is easier than landing a job directly in my opinion, and gives both you and your temporary department a chance to see if you are a good fit for each other.
cons: The pay is fairly low and, like many places, reviews are based on how much the department/company wants to increase your salary more than your actual accomplishments and achievements.  However, it does seems to be less so than I've experienced elsewhere. While easy to make career moves within the department, it was not as easy to move into another area since the University is so large and areas operate independently.

pros: Students are amazing, and many wonderful colleagues.
cons: Terms unclear, contract delays normal, poor pay

review_title: ULS- great resources, lousy business model
pros:
Free bus rides to get here
Great collection of materials
cons: I cannot recommend ULS to anyone who wants a career in librarianship.  The library relies very heavily on student employees, most of whom could not care less about the quality of their work.  Pitt knows that there is a constant stream of people who need part time employment to offset the ridiculous cost of tuition, so they devised a model wherein people with no training or interest in libraries work  for a few months until they quit and are replaced by another student.  The results are shoddy.  I don't blame the students; I blame the director (Rush Miller).  There's no shortage of professional librarians in Western PA willing to do quality work, but Rush obviously thinks 18 year olds can do the job just as good for a fraction of the salary.  Worst of all, they keep eliminating branch libraries and shifting the work branch librarians did onto staff at the main library.  In short, if you're working here and you're not a student employee be prepared to either get laid off or get extra work dumped on you in the near future.

review_title: Low pay; few opportunities for advancement
pros: Excellent health insurance, great retirement plan if you stay 3 or more years, university is closed over winter break/holidays.
cons: Low pay especially for internal employees, raises that don't even come close to the inflation rate, must work there for 6 + years before you get any additional vacation days, many ineffective managers who have been there for too long, lots of bureaucracy, unexciting professional development opportunities. Did I mention low pay? My salary is embarrassing compared to my friend who has the same job down the street.

job_title: Laboratory Research Technician in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Good retirement benefits. I also worked with great people who were not only qualified but also good people I got along with. There was a great team-oriented environment.
cons:
The University, particularly the school of medicine (I worked for the Department of Critical Care Medicine) is so bureaucratic to the point where they are ineffective. In my lab, the lab manager and all four technicians found positions elsewhere and quit within the span of two months. This was because of the toxic environment the higher ups created. No communication or room for growth. Pitt already pays an extremely low salary to it's research technicians, but we were willing to deal with it because we all loved our job and the people we worked with. However, it was clear to me, even after my exit interview with the operations manager, that the department did not value us as employees.
The operations manager actually talked about my lab manager in my exit interview and said things about her that we're "politically correct", but not professional to say in an exit interview.
I would not work at the University again and I'm happy that I've found a job elsewhere.

review_title: My experience was a poorly paid job with no room for advancement and misleadingly poor benefits.
pros: You are offered tuition reimbursement for some courses, and you have approximately a week off during Christmas and major holidays are off. Flexible with days off in my particular position
cons: The benefits are not that good.  They act like they will pay for your healthcare completely, but if you want a decent plan you have to play at least $150 per month.  Plus, the healthplans are not that good, I would frequently receive large bills that were not paid under my "premiuim" plan.  The salary was horrible.  You are only eligible for tuition benefits after 3-6 months of working there, and you can only take a maximum of 6 credits per semester.  If you plan to go to school, the lack of salary does not make up for "reimbursement".  You will incur less debt if you take out a loan and go full time. Also, the vacation and sick days are no different from any other job unless you work there for 10 years. Horrible management, and its impossible to get a raise.

review_title: Can be wonderful or terrible, depending on the department
pros: Most departments are full of really wonderful people who are super friendly and genuinely passionate about whatever services they're providing to students. Unless you're unfortunate enough to find yourself in one of the few really toxic offices, the positive culture is generally enough to make up for the cons (below). However, if you do find yourself in one of those offices: RUN, don't walk. They can be really ugly.
cons: Apart from unavoidable customer service-type annoyances associated with any university position, Pitt is notorious across the board for requiring an idiotic amount of red tape to complete the simplest tasks, which is endlessly frustrating. Also, if you're a graduate worker, get ready to be very under-compensated and insulted by the University whenever you point that fact out to them. Ultimately, though, that has less to do with Pitt specifically and is a more pervasive issue in universities across the country.

pros: Benefits are OK, there are professional development sessions offered, and if you plan to take classes and educate yourself...it's a great place to be. Classes are offered with a variety of options/times. Once you are a few years in, many departments can allow part-time employment.
cons: Pay is very low, they try to sell the low pay on the basis of giving "great" benefits like tuition breaks, but what do people, who don't use this, do? Plus lateral moves don't give pay raises and jumping ranks gives a 20% jump in salary... if you are lucky!! So if you start low, you stay low.Women faculty have less support, whether be mentorship or leadership. They have a lot of pressure to prove and re-prove themselves. Not much given for family support on campus, the day-care and pre-school slots are limited and no plans of expansion. The wait list can be as long as 5 years!!!

pros: Supportive of research; committed to campus-based learning and liberal arts education; deliberately not chasing the online education mirage and resistant to pure vocational school pandering (even though graduates have great career prospects)
cons: Byzantine bureaucracy. Rigid purchasing contracts that force you to buy overpriced, inferior products ($2.25/bottle of water; $8 for Costco-style wraps)--makes event organizing a pain. Unrealistic expense limits in Arts and Sciences that make it difficult to entertain colleagues. Max per person $60 including tax and tip; alcohol not to exceed 20% of per person cost before tax and tip, which means each person has a $40 limit plus price down.

review_title: Just as with anything, there is good and bad to working at the University of Pittsburgh
pros: There truly are great people at the University that are willing and able to help you advance, but you have to work hard to find them sometimes.  So much it dependent on the laboratory and department in which you work.  For graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, the mentor is so critical, and it really is a roll of the dice if yours will help you or happily let you take a backseat to their success.
cons: The University does not seem to value non-tenure faculty or even teaching faculty nearly as much as tenured, research faculty.  This has a definite negative affect on productivity and motivation.

review_title: Somewhat underpaid, but good benefits and work/life balance
pros: The benefits are quite good, including unlimited free access to public transportation. You also get health insurance even if you're only teaching one class (considered 10 hours per week).
cons: As a part-time instructor, my compensation works out to $18.00 per hour, pre-tax. In my opinion, that's too low for the highly skilled and specialized work I do, especially given the total lack of job security from semester to semester and the fact that most of us are lucky to get just two classes (20 hours per week). The end result is that we have relaxed schedules, decent health insurance, and perks like free transportation, but earn the equivalent of full-time fast food wages. Not a bad deal at all if you have a partner or spouse who can make up the income gap, but tough in any other circumstance.

review_title: Good for some people, not everyone
pros:
I have been working for Pitt for more than four years. I join Pitt as a junior level of software developer. I definitely learn a lot during these four years. The work environment is always relaxed and enjoyable. There're people who have been work for Pitt for over ten or fifteen years in my department.
Very good people. But I heard departments in Pitt vary from one to another.  
Great place for those who enjoy work and life balance.
cons:
In academic environment, the level of professionalization in building software for research purpose can't be compared to those for industry.  And a lot of products we build will get through away or discontinued because of the end of funding. Also it's very hard to measure success of a product because it's usually built for specific group of users, and the number of them is usually small. I have never talked to even one user of the products I built for four years. 
Not much opportunity for promotion. 
Universities usually pay less than companies.

review_title: Great employer overall. Specific job and department less so.
pros: Great benefits including retirement, medical, education. My job paid well for the type of work, but I can't speak for non unionized workers.
cons: The facilities department went through some much needed changes before I left, but  a few  of mid level supervisors are incompetent, and overcompensate by being very mean and unpleasant to their subordinates. This can make an already difficult and unfulfilling job, soul crushing.  The vast majority of them are all very nice and supportive, as long as you do your work.

pros: The benefits are really good, there is no question.  Thats pretty much it...
cons: The pay is still well below the national average even after the first initial reviews that were posted on here in 2011.  Raises are still impossible to get and if you do they dont even cover the cost of living increase.  Be careful who you accept an offer from.  Many P.I's and managers have a fake persona to get you to think it is really great there, and then once you are out of your probationary period it is like a switch is flipped.  Don't bother going to HR with a complaint as they will always side with the P.I and managers and you will be fired and blackballed throughout the Pitt system.  The turnover rate is sky high due to this.  My advice to you?  Take a position with caution and use to to get your feet wet and then move on.  Do not stray from your designated scheduled time even if they ask you to.

review_title: I don’t recommend working at Pitt unless you or a family member are also earning a degree.
pros: If you are earning a Pitt undergraduate degree or have kids going to Pitt, it’s a smart place to work, but don’t stay more than 5 years if you don’t have to.
cons: The University is becoming increasing corporatized and most of HR functions are outsourced, including MetLife “Total Absence Management.” No salary negotiation outside of tight pay grades and job classifications. We hear over and over that the University values its advisors and it’s emphasized in student recruiting. However, the University pays advisors very low, insulting, and immoral salaries yet gives us no respect, support, professional development opportunities, or even genuine encouragement.

review_title: Great Benefits, Good Culture, Low Pay
pros: The collaborative spirit in my department is amazing and my coworkers and supervisor are supportive and helpful. The medical benefits are topnotch, and we have access to a large array of employee programs, such as access to exercise classes, etc. Also, a very competitive 403-B match program.
cons: The salaries are, across the board, very low. There can be difficulty getting high-level administration to address the operating needs of specific departments, which leads to overwork and low morale. It is also difficult to move ahead without a master's or higher degree, which is incredibly discouraging and insulting to workers with proven experience.

review_title: Relaxed environment but with bureaucratic hoops and punishments
pros: My PI is great and allows me to come in and leave pretty much whenever as long as I get everything done and attend mandatory meetings (~2 per week). I put in my hours a
cons: I also attended Pitt as a student and since I owe them money, they won't allow me to work as an "All Temp" employee. This has created endless confusion for me and the administrators in my department as we've had to jump through hoops that make it hard for me pay back the money I owe them. Also, my PI must accept my hours online before a certain time and sometimes they don't do it in time, forcing me to wait another 2 weeks before getting paid.

review_title: It is what you make of it
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
* Great benefits
* Very generous amount of paid holidays for non-essential staff
* Amazing access to research resources
* The Office of Academic Career Development is a phenomenal university resource for post docs working within the medical school.
cons:
* It's a bit toxic: excessive over-working, trite politics, "passive" sexism, and low morale.
* The stress to publish and get grants leads to potentially sloppy science.
* Poor inter- and intra-department collaboration/ camaraderie. It's a fight for limited resources instead of support and sharing.

pros: Benefits, retirement, academic atmosphere, paid winter break
cons: If you come into this company with little experience and gain significant education and experience while you are there, it won't matter. You are forever wed to the salary you made upon entry. Throughout your time here you will get 10% increases in salary (all based on that initial salary) but will eventually find yourself supervising people who are new to the company and come into the job making way more than you do. There is no loyalty to employees who spend decades at the company developing and honing their skills. You have to leave the company to make the salary of others with the same level of education and experience.

review_title: Lots of Upside, Lots of Downside
pros: Conditions vary dramatically within different parts of the University, but the benefits are available to all employees.  The retirement plans are generous, and worth a look.  And of course, the tuition benefit is there for finishing graduate, undergraduate, or certificate work.
cons: This is a behemoth organization, and it moves like one.  Nothing happenes in a timely fashion.  Technology is not used here as it is in other sectors of the workplace.  For example, there is "no such thing" as working from home for anyone in our department in spite of the overwhelming proof that employees who are offered flexibility in how they accomplish work are happier and more productive.

review_title: Graduate Student Researcher PhD mechanical engineering program
pros: Strong education and selection of classes. Some opportunities to work with industry. Powerful computational resources (supercomputer). Lots groups performing experiments. Sharing of department-owned experimental equipment. Great machine shop available to students for research or education along with highly capable, highly experienced shop personnel. Teaching assistant scholarships available to qualified candidates.
cons: Compensation is what you expect for a graduate student (poor). Many risks for graduate students that are beyond their control. No one finishes your project for you. IE: you could be in graduate school for many years due to funding issues or inability to finish. Not all academic advisors are reasonable or invested in your graduation/success (mine was). Be careful which advisor you pick.

review_title: Allowed for ample time-off, but with very low salary and no opportunities for advancement.
pros: Laid back atmosphere in the psychology department.  Lots of paid vacation days.  Flexible vacation time. Free bus rides, and discounts for local museums.  Looks good on resume's and applications if you are interested in a research field.
cons: Very difficult to get "supposed" paid education.  Health, dental, and retirement are really not that good.  The plans are fine for basic day-to-day care, but when I had an ACTUAL health problem that required MRI's and CT's I was paying thousands.  The retirement fund is actually good if and only if you plan on staying for 10+ years.  However, there are literally no opportunities for advancement. So, if you are willing to keep a 20k salary for 10 years, than they will match your 401k (which Im guessing your contributions will not be too steep based on your salary).

review_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in the Physics department
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The professor was extremely knowledgeable and willing to help whenever I had a question or was stuck on a specific problem. My schedule was extremely flexible as I could come in any time of any day (even 2AM if I wanted!)
cons: It was easy and seamless to be given less and less meaningful work as I was approaching the end of my job. When I told my professor I wouldn't be coming back after the summer 2 months beforehand, I was given menial work that didn't help me learn. Always remember to make sure you're learning when you do undergraduate research.

review_title: Offensive & racially insensitive comments/behaviors + the mis/disinformation provided from HR led to resignation
pros: Health packages offered including paternal/maternity leave
cons:
Refusal to follow and/or acknowledge industry norms and standard business practices
Gaslighting and intellectual dishonesty when discussing difficult topics (racism, tokenism, classism) as it pertains to the the employer's hiring practices and admissions
Little to no racial or ethnic diversity amongst leadership, faculty, and accepted graduate students leading to passive exclusion and erasure
Little to no quality assurance in HR leading to disinformation provided to employees and government agencies regarding benefits, employee status, health plans, etc. and retaliation said HR reps - for example, the same PITT HR rep I filed a formal complaint on before my resignation appealed my unemployment compensation approval during the COVID global pandemic.

review_title: A very pleasant place to work
pros: Both the academic and the managerial staff are both helpful and knowledgeable in their handling of temporary staff such as myself. The pay is good, there is good co-operation between the management and the staff, and the people I knew there (I was in the chemical engineering department) all enjoyed working there.
cons: Really, the only cons were not to do with the University but the city. The area of Pittburgh where the University is (Oakland) is an expensive area to live, and so one must commute for some distance, meaning one has to either pay the costs of a car or wast time on the bus.

pros: The benefits are very good, including free tuition at Pitt, good health, care, decent vacation, etc.  If you have a good supervisor, it can be a very flexible and productive work environment with a fair degree of work-life balance.
cons: Each unit within the university seems to operate like its own fiefdom - there is considerable territoriality within departments and sectors of the university and so communication is not always great.  Because of this, there is oftentimes a fair amount of redundancy, which creates a weirdly competitive environment.  I think this is changing though as a younger generation moves in and approaches their jobs more as vocations rather than just jobs.  In the meantime, however, there can be a culture clash among older, long-term employees, and younger employees new to the system.

review_title: Not a good place for grant funded faculty position
pros: High caliber scientists as colleagues. Breadth of research programs and willingness of other faculty to collaborate.
cons: Salaries for tenure stream PhD faculty in the School of Medicine very disparate and not transparent. Scientific accomplishments mean nothing unless you have external funds to support your salary and research expenses. Even with sufficient funding you may lose access to resources unless you have patronage from the department head.  Most faculty are willing to "collaborate", as in have you work for free on their projects. Current trend is to throw money to the community at large for "innovation" with very little support from the institution on other matters. Innovation requires more than hosting "innovation tournaments" and "pitch competitions". The culture of support for real innovation does not exist yet. Big layer of "administrative staff" .

pros: Pitt has  wonderful employee benefits program including health/dental/vision, tuition reimbursement, and retirement and seems to recognize the importance of a work-life balance. The environment is basically laid back. There are also many perks (discounts on cell phones, port-authority bus pass etc...) that Pitt employees can enjoy.
cons: As with many companies, rising through the ranks at Pitt involves a lot of politics and bureaucracy. The salaries at Pitt are far less than those of comparable positions in the private sector. Most people are drawn to Pitt because of their superior benefits program, which I'm sure is unmatched anywhere else in the city.

job_title: Student Services Specialist II in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
Benefits are competitive, though expensive
Free transportation via the Port Authority
Educational benefits
Academic Environment
Oakland is a neat environment
Students are engaging
Offices with good atmospheres and staff are really good places to work
cons:
Departmental politics outweigh skill in your position. If your boss doesn't like you, your life is hell. 
Poor supervisors have no idea how to motivate their staff and instead focus on penalizing staff for minor issues. 
Little feedback - whether positive or negative - is given. 
Benefits are expensive and barely subsidized, especially in comparison to other universities.

review_title: Very flexible, great benefits, terrible pay
pros: Very relaxed environment in my lab. Nice jeans acceptable to wear, makes getting ready for work easy. Hours are very flexible, supervisor is OK with my schedule changing as needed (while still maintaining the 37.5 hours/week). Benefits are amazing, some of the best in Pittsburgh if not THE best.  You get all University holidays off (whenever University is closed).
cons: Terrible pay. Time off is accrued VERY slowly. When you first start working here, you are only given two personal days. Sick/vacation time is accrued each month. You earn 6.5 hours of vacation per month (a full day is 7.5 hours!).

review_title: put your time in then go
job_title: Systems Programmer II in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
A lot of IT stuff to play with.  You will learn a bunch.  
Everyone is miserable together so it's at least pleasant.
The job is over at the end of the day.
cons:
Schools are very segregated.  
You'll never meet people outside of your area unless it's like on the bus.
Hilariously inept middle management and strategy.  
The Peter Principle should be renamed the Pitt Principle
Doesn't pay well.
There is almost no accountability here.  Do what you want if you know what you're doing or not.

job_title: Animal Care Technician in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: It's good pay for the job, good benefits too
cons:
It's all about who you know at Pitt
If you start out at an entry level job or a lower level job people will look down at you, so be prepared for that. Those that move up in a position either know someone in management or know someone at HR. 
Lots of HR violations there, managers talk unprofessionally about employees. If you try to talk to HR they just tell the manager who you are and what you said and then your manager will have it out for you.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great if you have a 9-5 within the University community, however other jobs require LONG hours.  Good benefits, great, free, public transportation system for employees.  Many hospitals in the area offer various medical services especially using the University's health care plan.
cons: Traffic is terrible.  It's easy to get stuck in the same position for a long time.  The parking situation around the University is horrible, if you work here don't count on driving to work.  Public transportation is available and is pretty reliable in warm weather, but all bets are off when it gets cold.  The Oakland area is not very clean and some neighborhoods around the University are not safe after dark.

review_title: Meets my minimum expectations, though I can't imagine working here long-term
pros: The university has a lot of Influence in the region and there is a lot of support for the sports teams. It also isn't difficult to get the resources you need to do your job.
cons: Lesser staff is underpaid compared to other university libraries in the area. There is also a disconnect between higher-ups in the administration of the University and entry-level employees likely due to the size of the institution, similarly it can make the workplace feel impersonal.

review_title: Non tenure faculty are not valued
pros: The students are great. They want to do well and work hard to learn the material. Many of the support staff are absolutely fantastic and will do anything to help you out.
cons: There is no work life balance. And you are primarily evaluated based on anonymous student surveys of teaching quality even though the administration says that rigor is most important.  In over 5 years of working there, no annual raise ever met the increased cost of living.

review_title: Lots of opportunities, but poor pay and a swift boot at the first sign of conflict.
job_title: Research Specialist III in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: While at the University of Pittsburgh I gained valuable experience and became a published author.  I learned scientific techniques and numerous skills, gained insight into regulatory laws and protocols and greatly expanded my resume.
cons: Despite having extremely favorable reviews, I earned very little money and was constantly having to borrow from my parents to make ends meet.  Administrative staff informed me that the University is being extremely tight with salaries with regards to research staff.   Culture at Pitt looks down upon anyone without a PhD, and I was verbally abused by graduate students.

review_title: Pitt administrator speaks about the University.
pros: 401K Contribution is good and they offer a great variety of investment plans. I've been able to advance my career tearing down the careers of others.
cons: Culture of bullying by supervisors and managers. Too great a reliance on Theory X management practices. I took a seminar on "managing performance" and expected it to be related to encouraging and coaching employees but it turned out to be about how to document performance problems. Activist human resources department that gets too involved with day to day operations.  HR staff are mostly attorneys and I know of many settlements they have made to ward of age, race, hostile working environment suits.

job_title: Research Specialist III in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great benefits, including greatly reduced tuition, healthcare, and vacation time. Worked in a excellent lab that was highly interdisciplinary and had great colleagues. Feel like it is a good environment to be a technician
cons: Limited room for advancement and promotion. Your supervisor really has to fight and justify to get you an advancement in your position. It doesn't matter how long you work there or how productive, so there's definitely a very low glass ceiling for employees.

pros: In general, the benefits are fantastic.  Great employee matching for retirement.  We are given 2 free personal days a year.  There are a couple on-site fitness centers that offer classes and equipment at fairly inexpensive prices. We have free access to public transportation. There is access to childcare on campus.
cons: To make up for the amazing benefits, the pay is just so-so.  The maternity leave for staff isn't as great as I wish it was, and if both parents work at the University, they can only take a combined leave, not individual leaves.

review_title: Great place for a long career
pros: Great mission, friendly people, plenty of room/opportunity for career growth/upward mobility. Job security (tons of people who've been at Pitt for a very long time). INCREDIBLE health, education, and retirement benefits! Great place to work with a sense of real purpose.
cons: Very decentralized management around the University can make it difficult to get everyone on the same page or moving in the same direction. It makes change a very slow process. Salaries are lower than private sector (to be expected, but sometimes there can be a big gap). Also, insider thinking can be prevalent in pockets.

pros: It is fun to work in a university environment and they believe in doing things the right way -- with morals and hard work. Pay is low and it isn't easy to get a raise or promotion, but benefits are fantastic.
cons: The pay is not competitive and we were always short-staffed. We were consistently asked to do more with less. We found ways to make it all work, but it becomes exhausting. Talent and hard work isn't always the way to get promoted. Politics play into a lot of it.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great benefits and sensible policies.  Employees treated like adults and given independence to complete tasks as they see fit, no micromanagement.
cons: Salary ranges can be low for scientific positions compared to market value.  Annual raises for research staff past 10 years have always been below 3%, and thus new hires keep pace with experienced staff compensation.  Not much incentive for loyalty other than a few extra vacation days per year.

review_title: Great variety of positions available, not the best salaries, but good benefits.
pros: Good Benefits: health care, dental, vision, education, good retirement matching program (matching 1:1 for three years, after three years 1.5:1), good location in the city
cons: Parking is difficult to find/pricey, traffic can be bad during events and construction, Salary increases (sometimes frozen) not quite keeping pace with inflation.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Health Benefits, tuition stipend, and....nope that's about it.
cons: Being constantly harrassed by students, faculty, staff, and management for things you have no control over from the time you come in to the time you leave.  The pay is/was terrible with no raises in 2 years.  A few years ago during a terrible snowstorm I was not able to make it to work (state of emergency in Pittsburgh) and was docked vacation days instead of sick days.  Constantly being asked to do more and more with no incentive.  Even with the tuition stipend your pay is so low that you couldn't afford the 4-10%.  All round worst place I've ever worked.  I don't even like

pros: Overall the University is a friendly place to work.  The benefits are pretty good, if you can use them all.
cons: Great divides between leadership and the "worker bees".  Also, since it is higher ed, not a lot of interaction between the "intellectuals" and the staff.  Finally, had an intern that will be starting at a job paying more than my role and I have an MBA and over 30 years of experience.  Sad they pay staff so poorly, their own graduates do not want to work here.

pros: Nothing. This was the worst experience of my life.
cons: I had many issues with UPJ. This was the worst job to accept and I regret it everyday of my life. The upper management is terrible. They make decisions that don't make sense or to only benefit them, not the people below them. On my level, I didn't feel supported in my role. I wanted to learn more but I was always told that I had to know everything already. My supervisor did not support me and my coworkers were toxic. The benefits were terrible and I never took a day off because of the awful vacation package. Do not work at UPJ unless you want the world of higher education to be ruined forever. I am never going back into the field because of this unorganized soul sucking "university. "

review_title: Room to improve, but you could do worse! It all depends on your specific department.
pros: The students are terrific and the support staff are fantastic. These two groups of people make the overall experience worthwhile. There are pretty good medical benefits and the free bus service is wonderful for those living in the city limits and who can thus use the transit system.
cons: The University doesn't value non-tenure stream faculty and staff nearly as much as the tenure stream faculty. This greatly undercuts morale and productivity. Each department is a universe unto itself, creating a real lack of understanding of how to advance.

review_title: Low pay, but a good place to work
pros: Overall, I think Pitt is a good place to work.  The people here are generally nice, but the faculty can be a bit socially awkward. Very good 403 b matching program.
cons: For staff, the pay is very low.  There seems to be an expectation that staff people will work for pennies because the university offers a tuition break.  The benefits are OK, but nothing special.

pros: University environment is stimulating.  Interesting to learn about numerous topics taught and researched on campus. Energizing to interact with students and faculty. Free tuition for self, spouse or children, within guidelines. Free bus pass.  Central location with nearby amenities.
cons: Salary is below average for comparable job in private sector. Cumbersome internal administrative software and systems, versus state of the art technology and streamlined systems in private sector.  Tight budgets which limit what can be accomplished, but foster creativity for working within a resource challenged environment.

review_title: Working at the University of Pittsburgh is an educational experience with many rewards.
pros:
Educational benefits for employees and their families.
Pitt ID badge permits full time Pat Transit transport convenience allowing access to Pittsburgh's cultural district.
Growing and developing area creates many new opportunities for employees and students.
Beautiful buildings with historical value.
cons:
Traffic congestion with limited parking.  Limited parking increases parking costs.
Increased company benefits lowers the salary level.  Salaries and wage increases dependent on the state government which causes issues in the availability of yearly raises.

review_title: Great benefits but no room for advancement or increased salary
pros: Great benefits package for healthcare, retirement and education benefits for employee (and employee's spouse and children). Also great benefits package if you retire from Pitt. Great life work balance.
cons: Low starting salary for staff, suboptimal pay raises, and little to no room for advancement and if promoted low salary increases.  Also widely varied salaries amongst staff support where some who started when economy was better make almost double that of other staff with the same (or superior) skills but less tenure and newer hires have no chance to catch up. No incentive to go above and beyond because not rewarded financially for hard work.

review_title: Not too bad. Everyone is fairly nice. Seemed like they wanted us to learn. However, some bosses were obviously partial
pros: This opportunity was a very good learning experience for me. I learned a lot about things that will be important in the future
cons: My boss was obviously partial to some. It was in sustainability, and some people are more "hippy" than others. The professor took obvious sides. She would even say Hi to that person while not saying Hi to me

review_title: Excellent university, lots of flow, but little coordination
pros:
Great resources for students and instructors at all levels
Good feeling of "teamwork" in departments
Lots of emphasis on research
cons:
Pay is not competitive for the work expected of you at a top-tier research school
Little communication between departments and offices -- hard to find out what you need to know and who you need to talk to
Too much reliance on grad students

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great health benefits and free bus pass. Access to university activities, etc. is fairly easy. Many opportunities to move laterally through the organization but must be on the look out for these opportunities. Upward mobility is difficult in the same department.
cons: Difficulty transportation issue. The university (as most are) is very congested and it is very difficult to find reasonable parking within a few miles of the location. They pay was pretty low, but Pittsburgh has a very low cost of living. Additionally, senior employees could take off work whenever they please (i.e. unplanned absences) which leads to consistent work interruptions.

review_title: Benefits are great, salary is poor, and as a research tech, you will never get anywhere.
job_title: Research Technician III in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Phenomenal benefits and most of the people are nice and good to work with. It's a good place to start out and gain some experience, but get out as soon as you can.
cons: It doesn't matter how hard you work, or how smart you are, or how much of a contribution you make to the lab. If you are a research technician in a scientific research lab, when it comes down to it the PI will think about his/her money and that's it. Department administrators are out of touch and micro manage in areas they no nothing about.

review_title: Peer Tutoring/TA -- Good Student Job in Computer Science Department
pros:
The CS department pays it's TAs and Peer Tutors, and more than minimum wage. I haven't heard of many other departments that compensate as well.
It's great to be able to practice what you've learned by helping others who are learning the same things.
cons: The spaces we had to work were not always the most conducive as learning environments. We also didn't get much training, just let off the leash and mostly did what we felt was correct.

review_title: Werk Werk Werk WErk WERK - Rihanna
pros: Great environment to work in. Pitt has adapted well to changing times in the past is and is still a leader in thought and progress. There are lots of programs and benefits to take advantage of.
cons: Located in the city, obtaining a parking lease in a reasonable frame of time seems to be out of the question for most employees- not be an issue for those taking public transportation.

pros: University of Pittsburgh has outstanding benifits in all areas, and if possible you should take advantage of all of them. I went back and took classes at the University even though I already have a masters. Most of my co-workers in the Library system were outstanding and a pleasure to be around
cons: Low pay. Lots of staff members took the early retirement package so almost every department is understaffed and will not be replacing those who left. Administration has a top down approach, so nothing is allowed without their say so.

pros: You can find great researchers, as well as plenty of resources. Although sometimes not without glitches, communication across schools/departments is doable. Also, great city to live in.
cons: There is way too much bureaucracy, and unnecessary paperwork. The rate of staff to researchers is way too high, and staff is often not well prepared. Technology seems to be entering this university at turtle pace... a lot of paperwork and signatures are required for processes that in other places where I have worked have been automatized for over a decade. Absurd!

pros: Overall positive and flexible work environment.  Opportunities for collaboration with UPMC are great for research and practice-based professions.  Excellent benefits packages.
cons: Departments within the university do not communicate well with each other and record keeping systems vary across schools and departments, but could benefit from integration - or at minimum efforts to update paper files so as not to lose important information.  During my time there progress was being made in these areas and hopefully it will continue.

pros: Pittsburgh is an amazing city and Pitt offers so much to its employees. I really enjoy working with the students. They are dedicated and work very hard.  I love being able to get out into nature very quickly here. Benefits are top-notch!
cons: We're still working on improving diversity on campus. I'm disabled and people often have no idea how to help me or that established practices are rooted in able-ism. The university relies on adjuncts too much. And the pay is low, even for a city as inexpensive as Pittsburgh.

pros: Great Benefits, generally nice, relaxed environment and co-workers.  Friendly atmosphere with pretty flexoble work schedules.  If you need to leave early because of a doctor's appointment or a child's sports game, they don;t give you a hard time.  It is also not too formal, meaning you can almost always talk to yur supervisor like he or she is one of your peers.
cons: Not really any room for advancement, you have to pay for parking, not much recogniton for good work.  The pay isn't equivalent to what other companies pay.

pros:
Pitt is a good place to work for someone looking for an academic career in engineering. 
Nice people: professors, staff and students - very good and vibrant environment.
Reasonable compensation. 
Nice location - urban campus in Oakland area of Pittsburgh (close to CMU, museums and parks).
Academic calendar is nice - a lot of breaks and holidays.
cons:
It's a University - slow in processing paperwork or resolving issues. 
I am a part-time employee - there are no benefits for instructors.
Class schedules are set in advance, which makes it hard to balance with the other job(s).
Class times are not flexible.

review_title: solid working environment with room to grow
job_title: Budget & Contract Manager in Pitts, PA
pros: Pitt is a large university so it has room to move horizontally or vertically within the various departments of the university. Great benefits including education, health, retirement, etc.
cons: It is a hierarchical job pay/classification system (similar to a government job). It may take an employee a while to increase pay and bonuses are uncommon. .

review_title: Great people, big bureaucracy - Graduate School of Public and International Affairs
pros: I had a great boss who trusted and valued me a lot. Got to work with other graduate students and interview interesting professors, which was fun. I learned a lot about international affairs by writing about GSPIA's activities. I worked part-time her for 4 years and always felt very welcomed there. I would continue working at GSPIA if I could, but I wanted a job in my field.
cons: In this specific position I did not have to deal with the school's bureaucracy, but I know from my experience as a student that it can cause headaches.

pros:
Excellent 401K matching program and health benefits.
Good cost of living in Pittsburgh.
Much admiration for the efforts of the Chancellor and the Provost in establishing a world-class institution. 
Reputation as one of the leading research universities in the country.
Lots of good restaurants in and around campus.
Free bus transportation.
cons:
Salaries are lower than in business.
Director-level management is not supportive, positive, encouraging...many employees feel beaten down, berated, and held back by these managers.
Parking can be difficult and expensive, especially when classes are in sesssion.

review_title: Do not expect any real help or assistance with carrer advice present or future from faculty.
pros: As a whole, all University graduate students receive great health benefits and the cost of living in metro area is agreeable with your salary.
cons: The preliminary exams are often disjoint from the courses that are supposedly in place to assist you in passing the exams.  The preliminary courses also offer no insight into the true nature of mathematical thought that goes into research.

review_title: An unsatisfying top-level department that could easily be much better
pros:
-College campus environment: food, event, and outdoors options
-Benefits: retirement and free tuition (cost is fees & taxes only)
-Leaving at 5pm, rarely needing to work longer hours
cons:
-Below average pay compared to the regional industry standard. The highest raise possible is 3% so correcting this issue is, by default, impossible.
-Ineffective and unprofessional Office Manager who is sorely unqualified and was promoted from within over 20 years ago.
-Workload is not examined, assessed, and distributed appropriately to satisfy the demands of the department.
-Inefficient and technologically insufficient means of conducting work between, within, and from departments (Accounts payable, Legal, IT...)
-Very hard to be fired. In fact, several people will be assigned new areas of work rather than demanding that the problematic employee be expected to do their job. 
-Change is very slow to occur, if at all, even if a better method is proven and someone is able to help facilitate the change.
-No department meetings, ever.
-No relationship with direct boss over Office Manager, any communication that does occur is viewed as offensive by employees.
-Office morale is low and work environment is frequently uncomfortable and normally inefficient due to this.
-Office location, amenities, and physical appearance leave a lot to be desired.

review_title: I am currently a senior Communication major who tutors Public Speaking.
job_title: Public Speaking Tutor in Johnstown, PA
pros: I like working as a tutor at Pitt Johnstown because my hours were scheduled around my class schedule. As a public speaking tutor I can increase my public speaking skills. When no one needs tutored, I can do my homework.
cons: There is not many cons to working as a public speaking tutor. I can only get 3 hours a week because of my class scedule. The hourly wage is not the best.

review_title: Good benefits and balance, some chances for growth
pros:
-Good benefits (bus passes, discounts at museums etc, alongside standard medical etc)
-Oakland campus location - lots to see and do in neighborhood and surrounding areas
-Quality institution that is respected in the community
-Good work/life balance
-Mostly friendly colleagues
cons:
-Some instability due to government budget cuts
-Promotions are often based more on your professional degree rather than your proven results
-Lack of communication between departments can make things difficult and create confusion, overlap of duties/work, and waste

review_title: Not a bad place to work, but they're the only game in town, and they know it.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Jeffersonville, IN
pros: Good benefits package, health insurance is great for very little cost. There are a lot of postdoc positions at Pitt, so it's easy to find something that you enjoy doing.
cons: Postdocs sit in a weird in-between state, not faculty and not staff, so the benefits are a little less than faculty and staff, particularly with regard to retirement matching - postdocs do not get matching.

job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Jeffersonville, IN
pros: Education, retirement, and health benefits are great.  The ability to move laterally from departments is relatively easy. They match up to 8% for retirement then 150% of your 8% which is 12%.
cons: Very low pay and difficult to advance to higher paying jobs as those people stay for decades.  Must work several weekends with no extra pay with only 1 comp hour for an entire Saturday of work

pros: One of the greatest institutions in USA, rank of the University 's programs is consistently rising year after year.  Money is being reinvested in the University for new buildings, the campus looks better every year.  The city is very affordable, especially for those in graduate school, plenty of things to do around the school and around town.  Public transport is free to students, and getting around town is easy, don't need a car.  Easy to fall in love with Pittsburgh, a surprise to many people.
cons: The campus is separated because part of it is located on a very steep hill.

review_title: Low pay, long hours, impossible to advance
pros: Pitt has a great benefits package available to employees, facilities are in great locations (easily accessible from all parts of town)
cons: Incredibly low pay when compared to national average, virtually impossible to move up a salary grade, expected to work weekends/overtime with no compensation (comp time to be taken/overtime pay)

review_title: The University of Pittsburgh offers very good benefits along with a good salary.
pros: The benefits offered include medical, dental, vision, paid time off, a 401K plan, as well as tuition assistance.  The salary is decent, especially as you move up the ranks.  Our department and the university both took great pride in exceeding standards.
cons: The budget allocated to our department seemed to leave us short on the staff numbers we felt we needed.

review_title: UPJ is great, Johnstown is small
pros:
UPJ has a good work environment. 
The student body has some excellent students. 
The campus is beautiful and in a great location for learning. 
The department is very good. My colleagues are great to work with.
cons:
Johnstown itself is very small, so you might get bored.
It is very cold in the winters here, so make sure you're okay with that.
The pay could be better, but you aren't in academia to make money!

review_title: great place to learn and work as a student
pros: Open environment, great place for collaborations, great research opportunities at the university, hospital, and CMU. amazing place to learn research techniques and work with leading professors in the field. professors are open to new ideas of students and offer great support when starting in a completely new field.
cons: Balancing school and research as a student is difficult but worth it. not paid over-time as a student. lab had many undergraduate students and value of research experience largely depended on research mentor one was paired with. fewer undergraduates would allow for more personalized attention to all.

review_title: Good place to work at times
pros: This review is written based on my second go around at Pitt as an employee (I was a student/employee previously as well in another department). The benefits are great, the amount of vacation/sick time you get from the start is just phenomenal. I didn't get to use the health benefits as much, but I got to use the dental and vision to the fullest extent.  The dental coverage was great, at worst case I paid 15% of the total cost of a procedure, and best case (which was most of the time) it was fully covered. My particular managers were great, understanding, and understood what work life balance meant. They treated people as individuals, and it was a fun environment that was still professional. I had family issues that my managers took seriously, and personally as they could understand my situation, and made sure I had everything I needed. In my short time at the department, I learned far more than I did in internships and school itself. I know that in many reviews people say the University is lacking in many ways, but it depends on your department and your coworkers. I can honestly say, that my team felt like a family, and that the experience helped my advance my career. There were thought days when deadlines were approaching/arriving, there were fun days when you got to learn new technologies and techniques you never knew existed. For many professions, especially the engineering profession, the University is a great place to develop and contribute.
cons: The pay was much lower than you would get in a corporation (they tell you this up front, I was told this in my interview). The one thing that bothered me specifically was that a person doing basic IT work (computer troubleshooting, simple maintenance, tech support) that started six months before me made more than I did as a software developer. Another con, as mentioned in other reviews, the pros/cons will depend on your department and your managers. As I said in my pros, my direct managers were great. Their manage however, would talk unprofessionally about employees, included my managers to my face, discussing it with HR does bring it back up to the highest most manager, and it continues the loop. There was a point that I would just avoid that manager. From said manager, employees were insulted, belittled, and degraded, especially if their ideas were better than said manager's. In terms of career opportunities, not a whole lot exist. You can move up slightly, and they usually put you in a position that they can still give you a decent raise (mind you still below corporate levels), but the work you will be doing will generally be the same whether you are a junior or senior developer.

review_title: Decent place to work with excellent benefits
job_title: Research Specialist IV in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
Great benefits package, especially retirement. After you are vested the university matches your contribution 150%.
You also get  ample vacation time, including a week off at Christmas/New Year. Free public transportation. A lot to do around campus.
cons: The traffic is bad and the parking is even worse. You have to get on a waiting list to get a parking pass.

pros: The University of Pittsburgh is full of great people to work with - most of them are truly here for the right reasons and have a passion for higher education.
cons: There is not much room for advancement, depending on the department you are in. Student Affairs is constantly worried about metrics (which is fine in some cases) and numbers over quality of programming.

pros: bus pass, insurance, retirement matching are all very good. the people i worked with at katz were mostly awesome. location in oakland is fun
cons: abominably low pay. despite the published pay scales they will lowball you. I negotiated up and got a teeny bit more a year, but prob not even 1,000. ive heard it helps if you can come in with a higher salary already.

pros: If you're interested in research, Pitt is definitely a place to be. There are so many entry level positions to start your career. The benefits and time off are decent and you get at least 90% off tuition if you're looking to continue your education.
cons: The HR system is a disaster. It's nearly impossible to get a raise as a research assistant based on your work. My supervisor submitted a request to HR to give me a raise and it was denied. The salary is next to nothing, but the education benefits made up for it for me.

review_title: Great place for life/work balance, but salaries have been flat for almost a decade now
pros: Tremendous holidays/vacation/time-off. Great retirement and medical benefits, and tuition too. Most staff members were pleasant to work with. And the workload was slight compared to corporate (pay reflects it, lol)
cons: Few advancement opportunities. Pay is low. A few incompetent employees in other departments were impossible to get accurate, timely information from and there was little recourse to resolve such issues.

review_title: Pay is low, good place to work, people are nice, competition never exceed collegiality.
pros: Academic environment. Lots of interactions with peers and support from others. Research facilities are cutting edge. Core facilities not expensive. Many reknowned faculties around. Lots of opportunities to learn.
cons: Not a good place for aspiring post-docs trying to become faculties. Salary is low and not much opportunity to grow.

review_title: Great Place depending on your department
pros: Great benefits and time off.  Opportunities to get involved in other areas through committees, staff organizations and volunteer opportunities.
cons: Career advancement is solely dependent on your department-some departments have clear promotion tracks while others do not.  Salary is capped so that you can only earn 10% more when you change jobs.  It is better to leave the university and be hired back at a higher salary than count on getting a significant increase on a yearly basis.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student In Bioengineering in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
I am a PhD graduate student in the department of Bioengineering at the University of Pittsburgh. Overall the department is supportive and interested in your success.  They offer a course to first-year PhD students to help them compete for NSF and F31 pre-doctoral fellowships. Students have a lot of freedom when I comes to which courses they can take for their degree. This allows graduate students to take courses that are closely related to their research.

Compensation is good enough to live in Pittsburgh, but it's not showing off money. However, the graduate student medical benefits are extremely good.
cons:
As with any PhD program, the individual graduate student experience will depend on your lab and thesis adviser. Some advisers are more interested in mentoring you than others. However, again, as with any PhD program it is difficult to know who are the "good" mentors before you join their lab. As with all PhD programs, sometimes the department will help you solve a bad mentoring situation, and sometimes you will have to over-come the situation on your own. 

At the end of the day, as with all Universities,  the faculty bring in the money not the graduate students, and once a faculty member is tenured to a department, the department itself can't make them be a "good mentor".

Based on my personal experience in the biosignals and imaging track, I would rate my experience in the Bioengineering Department to be a good one overall. I would definitely recommend the Bioengineering Department at the University of Pittsburgh to anyone looking for a PhD in Bioengineering. 

Make sure you take a look at the research available though, and definitely contact people you think you would be interested in working with before you apply to: 1) make sure they have money, and 2) because it may help you in the application process to already have a couple faculty members in mind that you want to work with.

Work-life balance is difficult for all PhD programs, especially science/engineering. If it offends you to work late  or on the weekends, you might want to think about if a PhD is really for you. Grad school is NOT like undergrad in any way.

review_title: U of Pitt, A Great Place to Work, Amazing Benefits, Pay Leaves Something to Be Desired
job_title: Technology Development Specialist in Lancaster, PA
pros: It's difficult to rate the entire University of Pittsburgh. It's a massive employer with many arms... large, medium, and small. In my medium-sized segment, one of the schools in an off-campus branch location, the company was a great place to work. I was there for almost 19 years. Of course it had it's issues, all work places do once the shine wears off. However, in retrospect, leadership from the main campus and in our location generally cared about your personal and professional health and well-being. The location was state of the art and A+ rated real estate. Learning opportunities abounded. The benefits were spectacular.
cons: While they generally offered annual pay increases (depending on how well the university is doing financially in any given year), the pay associated with professional positions is generally not commensurate with the position. I didn't realize how little I made in comparison to other similar positions in the private sector... one half to, eventually, one third of what was possible and what I now make for doing the same job. In addition, a major issue with my location was that there was simply no opportunities for upward movement (and the resulting increased pay). Once people obtain a job with the university, they tend to stay for life... as the educational and retirement benefits are amazing. However, until you near retirement age (or unless you take full advantage of the education benefit... difficult when I was employed there as they were just ramping up online courses and we were not on the main or even on a major branch campus location), you simply don't make enough compared to similar positions in the private sector.

review_title: Being a research assistant as an undergrad is a great experience so you know if the R&D field is for you.
pros: You will gain the following as an undergrad research assistant: connections, research experience, analytical capability development, and increased communication and teammwork skills.
cons: If you're stuck with grunt work, it can be tedious and boring. If you don't communicate regularly with your professor about the work you're doing, you may feel like the work your doing doesn't matter due to miscommunication.

review_title: the experiences of graduate students seem to be highly variable
pros:
As indicated in my title, I think the experience of any given graduate student depends highly on the specific department/program/advisor.  So, that said, take all of this with grain of salt -- both the pros and the cons.

Pros: 
(1) Between Pitt and CMU, I felt like I had access to a very large, talented community of scientists.  I met a lot of very very smart people, both at the trainee and the P.I. level. 
(2) I also felt like I had no trouble accessing the resources I needed -- financial resources, research tools, etc -- in order to do good work. 
(3) It seemed like the need for independent thought and individual growth was prioritized and respected.  I didn't feel like I needed to be concerned about the consequences if I expressed disagreement, or wanted to try something new/unconventional.
(4) Medical benefits were good. 
(5) Pittsburgh is an inexpensive place to live.
(6) I didn't feel like it was too stressful of a place to work.
cons:
(1) The city also has its downsides -- Some of the rental housing is very, very poor, and if you plan to rent, you should start searching very far in advance (3-4 months) if you want to find a good place.  And while it is true that Pittsburgh is not the gritty steel city of yore, it's still not the most eco-friendly place on the planet -- It is often ranked as one of the more air-polluted cities in the U.S.  It has a lot of things going for it, also, but I would be sure to check out the city thoroughly before moving there, to see if its pros and cons meet your needs/wishes.
 
(2) So, I had two general concerns about Pitt, which both fall into the category of vague impressions, so it might be worth consulting other reviews to see if other people feel the same way.  First, the adjective that kept coming to mind when I worked there was "sclerotic" - a little bit behind, wedded to the past, and I was concerned sometimes that there was more interest in celebrating senior faculty members than in helping see to the success of the junior faculty that came in.  Second, I seemed to know of more P.I.'s than usual who struck me as being on the really problematic side, with respect to their general comportment and how they treated others.  I'm sure that they were still just the outliers of an otherwise normal community of people, but they managed to have a knack for drawing a lot of attention to themselves.

pros: Vibrant, interdisciplinary environment. One of the best places to work for any biomedical-related area, and Pittsburgh is growing to be a major hub for Neuroscience and Engineering. The collaboration between Pitt and CMU, which is right next door, is one to watch out for.
cons: The university itself can diversify from being a intellectual hotbed for biomedical fields to other engineering and tech fields (although the presence of CMU next door makes that a non-critical requirement).

review_title: Great Benefits, Awful Pay, Outdated Admin Approach, Lacking an Inclusive Culture
pros: Transportation and education benefits are probably unmatched by most local employers. Lively student atmosphere invites new ideas and excitement around research and innovation.
cons:
The pay is incredibly below market, and unless you have kids who are planning to go to school at Pitt, the benefits do not make up for the pay gap. 

Pitt is very hierarchical and rigid - innovators, beware! Unless you are willing to play political games, you are unlikely to get a pay raise or promotion, regardless of your skill level or willingness to take on new responsibilities. 

Management was unwilling to discuss goals and metric benchmarks for my position (despite multiple requests to do so). Outside of self-assessment and personal benchmarking, I was provided little opportunity to identify departmental goals and demonstrate progress in my position. I ultimately left because I was being asked to increasingly manage new programs and people, but was not given a clear understanding of the planned progression of the role / was denied appropriate job mobility and compensation for the expanding responsibilities.

In my experience, management’s focus was on looking good rather than doing good.  The University is very concerned with its image and will default to the path of least resistance to maintain the status-quo. Do not expect to be inspired by the University’s leadership. 

Most transformational change is at the grassroots level from passionate staff, faculty, and students, but their ability to affect long-term change is limited by a lack of investment and engagement by leadership. 

The culture for my department had an “old boys club” vibe with lots of passive sexism and insensitivity to gender/LGBTQ issues. People also openly discussed their religion as if they were at their personal Church / as if everyone believed the same thing.  Not a diverse place. 

Additionally, all of our filing and admin systems were incredibly out of date with excessive paperwork and data entry. Do not expect a modern or efficient office environment.

pros: Fantastic colleagues and a lot of networking ability. They also provide amazing benefits, especially the retirement benefits. Some supervisors will let you work a flexible schedule which is nice!
cons: HR will do the minimum to assist you if there are issues with your supervisor. Basically they tell you to just find another position, but they will not transfer you or enforce their harassment policy.

review_title: Benefit:Salary ratio heavily skewed to pay you as little as possible but keep you there
job_title: Research Assistant III in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Benefits are beyond are by all means the best part of working at Pitt.  Amazing medical insurance is relatively cheap and the educational benefits are astounding.
cons: Unfortunately such great benefits come at the cost of a decent salary.  And career progression is very unlikely unless you are willing to move departments which can be difficult.  In addition, if there are benefits that you do not take advantage of you are unable to opt out of them to increase your salary.

review_title: It is a very nice place to do research, especially in health care, upmc is a very top-level teaching hospital
pros: The city has a lot of places to explore in terms of culture, sports, music, arts. The location is great and people are very friendly.
cons: The weather is not very good because it is located in the north, winter is very long, with a lot of snow for some years.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: You're job is to work toward a degree while gaining excellent and needed experience in your intended field.  Plus, it pays for school and you can earn a doctorate without incurring debt.
cons: It's what you would expect from a position as a graduate student, there is a lot of work and you have to juggle competing time constraints such as course work and milestones.

review_title: Great place to work and live
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
