It's a great place to live and work.  Advantages of a big city without the cost. 

Your experience as a postdoc at Pitt will likely vary tremendously depending on your advisor.  But for me, I have a good bit of autonomy in my research and opportunities for collaboration
cons: Same as every postdoc job.  Bad salary, long hours. And you still have to pay back your student loans

pros: Really care about getting students hours, allow students to do homework in downtime, staff was really nice, delivered mail around campus so I was always getting exercise! Pay used to be monthly, but now it's biweekly, so that's great!
cons: Sometimes I'd get all of my homework done and stare at the wall for an hour until my shift was up. If they let student workers into Peoplesoft, I would've been able to help my supervisors more and rarely be bored!

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The University is very flexible with your working habits, and the department that I work for is great! The people are very close, and have departmental get-togethers frequently. The student positions do not all require work study, although there are more positions open for those who qualify for work study.
cons: The pay is not very competitive, and unfortunately I had to turn down work study in order to take out the necessary amount of loans to pay for school. For non-student employees, however, the pay is supplemented with a good benefits package.

pros: The whole environment is great. My team members are very friendly to me, and you can enjoy many benefits from university, such as you can select courses for free.
cons: Since this is a part-time position, it may not be a best choice if you are looking for a great career, but you can know a lot of great people here, and they may refer you a better job.

review_title: Graduate Researcher at U. Pitt Main camus
job_title: Graduate Student Scholar in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: I had access to the latest technology and methodology.  There were many exciting research programs being conducted.  I also had access to distinquished scholars from around the world.
cons: I would have like more supervision from my advisor and the guarantee of being funded through out my tenure in the program.

pros: Casual atmosphere. Good location in Oakland. The best best benefit package you could possibly imagine.
cons: Faced some upper level resistance to vertical movement within my specific department despite my supervisor supporting the move/raise.  Also, there was a pay increase freeze (now over) that lasted over a year.

review_title: Not a lot of "love" for Finance people
pros: Great benefits if you can use them.
cons: Pay for someone in my position outside of this organization is $20-30k higher.  I will give up the recess in December for that much more pay.

review_title: The company was great to work for, with flexible hours and numerous educational benefits.
job_title: Systems Analyst III in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The University calendar allows you a full paid week off during the winter holiday and many paid holidays off, which is uncommon in the workplace. There was substantial collaboration between physicians, technologists, chemists and analysts which allowed for a lot of growth.
cons: Many of the positions were grant-based and with the tightening of the budget for the NIH and other federal funding, quite a few people lost their jobs because of a lack of funding.

review_title: Great place to work and get an education
pros: The University is a great place to work - the benefits are tremendous, especially the education benefit.  I obtained my MBA while working here and am considering starting another master's program soon.
cons: Advancement can be difficult without switching jobs or departments, depending on your area of expertise.  Salary increases may be limited to cost-of-living which is minimal.

pros:
Diverse work environment 
Great of you have kids
Work life balance if you have kids
Lots of green space on campus
cons:
Not great if you don’t have kids 
Pay is low because they pay for your kid to go to school. But if you don’t have kids no additional salary
No work life balance if you do not have kids

pros: They were flexible with the schedule. The office was really friendly. ( They celebrated your birthday) Things never felt hectic. Nothing felt too complicated to do.
cons: As a student worker, you are an extra helping hand and not too much part of the office. You do the same maintenance and delivery type of stuff no matter how long you've been there. You don't gain new skills.

pros: Lots of brilliant people, lots of camaraderie, many interesting events, and many opportunities to pursue research through avenues both within and without your Department.
cons: Culture of "publish or perish" in full swing without faculty even considering the possibility of careers outside of academia, political infighting within the professorship, lack of cooperation across departments, instances of bullying.

review_title: Good for the lifestyle and benefits
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: the city, its a fun town and the cost of living is quite low, so it attracts a lot of students/artists etc. carnegie mellon university and the university of pittsburgh are quite renowned in certain area - robotics and computer science/engineering for carnegie mellon and the medical school for U of Pitt. the university areas - largely oakland- are very lively because of the large number of students, as are the surrounding areas of shadyside, lawrenceville, bloomfield, squirrel hill etc. world class museums, beautiful parks and ok (well, reasonable) weather make it a great lifestyle if you find a suitable job in the University.
cons: Pay scale is low compared to the private sector

review_title: It's a good place to do science, build up a network of knowledge
pros: Pitt has a good reputation in biomedical sciences, which is my major in graduate school. With extensive collaboration with its medical center, researchers at Pitt have ample access to clinical samples, and are able to translate their researches from bench to bedsides. Plus, pitt has wonderful benefits program for graduate students, including excellent health insurance, tuition waiver, discounts on many software, port authority bus pass, etc.
cons: Communication between different schools, parking is very limited and expensive on campus

review_title: Great Environment for Diversified Opportunities and Learning
pros: Excellent Benefits, many diversified opportunities, had many great co-workers, if you have a great manager it makes all the difference.
cons: Parking is expensive if you work in Oakland so it is great if you can bus it to work. Lack of trained professional management in some departments, but having a professional, personable  manager minimized cons.

job_title: Administrative Support III in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: It is a great opportunity for current students! The experience I am sure depends on the specific department you are a part of, but my department was great and very flexible around my school schedule!
cons: The university only has pay days on the last day of the month for all employees: both work study students and full time hires. It can be really inconvenient only getting paid once a month.

review_title: A decent place to work, with good benefits
pros: Working at University of Pittsburgh provides opportunities to learn new technologies and meet interesting people. The work and life balance depends on which department you are in and what kind of work you do. The benefit is good including healthcare insurance and 401K. If your kids will go to U Pitt one day, working here will save you a lot of money.
cons: The salary is so so, especially for people doing research and graduate students. Promotion is not an easy thing happened here.

job_title: Research Specialist II in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: There are plenty of academic resources you have access to as an employee that you otherwise would definitely not be able to afford.
cons: Incompetent, lazy, and back-stabbing researchers/lab managers/PIs are rampant. It is frustrating for someone that wants to get work done. They also pay highly qualified, competent, and enthusiastic workers dust for the amount of work that is expected of them. Go research somewhere else.

pros: My program was a world-class program; the university rewarded it with the extra funding it deserved given the results it produced.  I had a special personal situation and I always felt that my department/work unit treated me fairly with regard to it, including the unpaid leave I was looking for.
cons: The university does not necessarily play well with the city at large.  Undergrad students are not terribly motivated.  I know that other departments depend on poorly paid part time faculty and are squabbling.

pros: I enjoyed working for University of Pittsburgh (Pitt). The work hours were great. I worked 4-10 (Tue-Fri, 7:00 AM - 5:00 PM) for most of my 3 years there. My boss was very understanding/accommodating. My co-workers were knowledgeable and professional. We had our share of differences on how to approach but we never stopped that from keeping our work environment friendly and cordial.
cons: I can't think of any major cons. Maybe higher salary?

review_title: Being a paid graduate student can be amazing and terrible.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Health care, pay ratio for the cost of living in PGH, funding availability, diversity of research fields, especially in the biosciences.
cons: IT is pretty bad.  Pitt relies on some pretty antiquated systems.  A lot of systems have been updated recently.  Protection for graduates students from abuse differs by department.   Some departments have absolutely no intervention.

review_title: Research assistant at the University of Pittsburgh
pros: Free and friendly atmosphere. Good balance between work and life. Equipment, such as computer, scanner, and printer, is freely available. Payment is good considering the CPI.
cons: Sometimes it is stressful to work here. Need to maintain good relationship with boss. Collaboration among groups is rare. Funding is not guaranteed all the time. No windows in the office.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine is one of the best schools for doing a PhD in microbiology and immunology. The professors care about the students' well-being and research progress. There are resources for mental health issues. You can live comfortably with the stipend provided. Facilities and breadth of research are particularly excellent. Pittsburgh is also a great city to live in! There are plenty of parks around and lots of events happening specially during the summer.
cons: Can't really think of any right now

pros: very nice and competent people, good location and area, provides employees with the use of gyms and free bus passage
cons: paychecks at end of the month following your work (october work paid after thanksgiving, etc.), at my office, personal reasons for missing work were very often questioned when the reason was for a very serious matter

pros:
Ability to operate as you will.
Great sick and vacation time.
cons:
Heavily department based little to no centralized services or events.
Generally low salaries.
Poor HR management, often wants to fire or let people go rather than find new places for them.

review_title: good place to work and study
pros: Interesting work with no limit to what you can learn from some extremely brilliant and talented people. , the work/life balance became more reasonable, but even when it was nuts, i
cons: some projects came out of nowhere, and one micromanager caused 30% attrition by making a few talented, hardworking contributors feel extremely frustrated and marginalized.

pros: A lot of training opportunities such as various weekly seminars in different departments and periodical career development workshops;  best benefits such as dental/medical/vision, etc.
cons: Relatively low income; some core facilities should be updated to meet the state-of-the-art standard. Research treat  (more than 1 day) for Ph.D. candidates and postdocs  should be arranged to enhance the scientific communication and socialization.

review_title: Great resume building first job, poor long term career prospects
job_title: Software Development Team Lead in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
Great co-workers.
Great work-life balance.
Great resume builder.
Great first job.
Great vacation and holiday schedule.
cons:
Pay scale is about 40% lower than for-profit companies.
Parking is practically non-existent.
Nepotism on TAX funded projects, boss would always hire his friends, who would ALWAYS fail, and then he would have to pay a second group to fix the problems his friend created.  Watched this happen 4 times while I was there.

pros: The university provides their employees with good benefits. Also, the working environment is friendly. Work/life balance is definitely a plus.
cons: Unfortunately, this is one of the lowest paying universities in the area. Also, the quality of benefits has been slowly eroding.

review_title: Ok place. But hard to stay on long term.
pros: Adequate pay. Good health insurance. Depending on the PI you work for, you can have lots of freedom to pursue varied research interests.
cons: Typically postdoc employment is based on a contract that must be renewed annually (same is true for many faculty positions). In the psychiatry department, promotion to faculty is dependent on receiving a specific type of NIH grant (K01). Therefore there is really only one avenue for success, which makes it hard to stay on long term.

pros:
-typical research university setting, however such a large university does offer more resources than some smaller schools
-post-doc positions are variable in every aspect, but there is an active program to promote collaboration
cons:
-of course the pay is very low for a Ph.D. level position but that is standard for post-docs
-the benefits are poor, no retirement, matching of funds or otherwise for post-docs, healthcare is through UPMC which

review_title: Great place to work in the city of Pittsburgh. You get a chance to use your skills and talents plus receive great benef
job_title: Undergraduate Program Administrator in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: You get a chance to use your skills and talents.  The benefits are great and you have the option to continue your education.
cons: As a staff member, the option of getting a higher level position is minimal.  The pay is not too bad.

review_title: I worked as Research assistant here
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The academic environment here is perfect for conducting scientific research and learning new stuff  as well as making progress every day
cons: the computer resources are not very sufficient some times. Also the library often closes on weekends/holidays very early so if you want to find a quiet place to study it is hard during these times.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: It has a great Medical school for life science researchers (UPMC), Many departments and large no of labs. Very well qualified faculties with vast research experience of good publication record, good graduate training program which produces very high quality students every year.
cons: Funds are drying up, there is not enought grant available.  Lack of stable and longer duration Post-doc fellowships, comparatively low pay for post-docs than other graduate schools.

review_title: A decent enough place to work
pros: Great Benefits,  good learning experience. wide exposure new idea and technologies. The quality of working there really depends on what department you are in and who your manager is.
cons: U of Pitt can be either a great or bad place to work depending on what part of the Univeristy you work in... Pay and raise are so, so. There is a large amount of favoritism going on in the place.

review_title: Great place to work, job security
pros: Plenty of opportunity for staff.  Work is challenging and the workload is reasonable. The benefits are second to none with fantastic 403b matching.
cons: A lot of times your degree or degrees mean more in getting a job than your actual skillset or expertise.  Doesn't always matter what the degree is or whether it is relevant.  Prevents the best people from always getting the job.

review_title: Pre-Doctoral Fellow in Biological Sciences Department.
pros: FYI I work in the department of biological sciences. The people are very nice. The research we do here is very interesting and meaningful.
cons: Pay is low (not just for grad students), but this is the nature of academic work I suppose.

pros: Working on campus is fun and exciting. Coworkers were great and very supportive, almost like a second family. Benefits and PTO are great.
cons: Salaries are low and the raises are small if you get one at all, as is the case with most universities. Only way to get a raise is to get a promotion but it can be difficult to advance within the university, it seems like you really need to know the right people.

review_title: Great place to live a life as a graduate student researcher
job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
The school has wonderful leaders who are easy-going, and close to the students. 
The school is a research-oriented university that is well-known within the U.S. as well as across the countries. 
Given the relatively low life expense (compared to other cities like NYC), the compensation for graduate students doing research assistant and/or teaching assistant work is fairly attractive.
cons: The fundings are competitive, I mean, very competitive, especially for social science departments.

review_title: Among best academic places to work
pros: Large, well-respected campus. Great opportunities for many people. Strong emphasis on students, as well as research.
cons: Continuing budgetary pressures from state cuts year after year, growth in programs (teaching and research) not matched by capital improvements at the same rate.

job_title: Research Assistant III in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: There are numerous opportunities to continue your education and training. Benefits are excellent! Healthcare and free bus pass. Also, there are plenty of opportunities to attend games and arts venues with half-priced tickets.
cons: Most of the research assistant jobs are grant funded so be prepared to only have a temporary position in most cases.

pros: first temp placement was great--awesome office atmosphere, felt helpful/needed; temp recruiter was nice
cons: second temp placement is miserable--I have almost zero work to do (nice at first but I'm getting annoyed with it now) and I feel completely unnecessary and unneeded

pros: It's an awesome environment to work in and the people there are generally very nice. Of course the health insurance is great as well.
cons: The pay is terrible across the entire campus. Some of the managers are morons and you will see them spend money on the most ridiculous things while you struggle to pay bills. Avoid working here at all costs.

pros: Pittsburgh has its bright spots, and Pitt is in a centrally located part of the city. It's a large university with many events and course offerings.
cons: The university clamps down on anyone who does not tow the "company line." Between the university and the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Pittsburgh is quickly becoming a one-company town. If you get sick and have to go to UPMC, you will literally owe the "company store."

pros: If you want to be in a place where there is new and cutting edge research everyday this is the place.  As a graduate assistant, compensation was fair and work life balance was reiterated. It is a great place to get research experience as the collaboration possibilities are numerous.
cons: Not having a long range financial compensation plan.  It ors by the year but they are really good at getting funding especially for doctoral students.

pros: The benefits are outstanding and a key reason for holding onto good people. I worked for two departments and had  mostly positive experiences. Changed positions when management changed.
cons: Pay is below market. See comment about benefits.  Each school has its own way of doing business so the same job in two departments is not necessarily equal.

review_title: Great Place to Gain Consulting, Small Business Experience
pros:
Entry level consulting, talented management
No one is there for the money (there isn't much), people are genuinely interested in your success
You'll work with lots of different start ups in various industries
cons: Because you work with so many start ups, don't expect to do too much work for any of them, you'll learn to put people through a system

review_title: Only if you want great benefits
pros:
Great Benefits and Retire Plan
Free Public Transport with ID
cons:
Expect to get paid in the lower end of the pay range
Lack of proactive training or keeping up with commercial industry
Most people have been there for years so they are not motivated to do better
Not the best place to start a young career

review_title: An excellent opportunity to earn credit or some side cash.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
Manageable workload- there are usually enough TA's that the workload is manageable while a full time student with a part time job.

A great way to meet other students and make new friends.
cons: If you opt for $$ instead of course credit, you may be dissappointed in the value received for the work you do. In other words, the pay is borderline slavery. 6-8 hours of work/week for ~$75

review_title: Computer lab consultant bosses take it all too seriously.
job_title: Computer Lab Consultant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
-Very flexible hours
-Easy to maintain a work life balance
-Interview quite easy
-Easy to pick up more shifts
-Summer work a bit more difficult
-A lot of downtime - easy to catch up on schoolwork or reading for fun
cons:
-No room for growth
-Harsh supervisors - take the consultant job way too seriously
-Uniform is way too strict for what you do

review_title: School of Education Technology Help Desk
pros: Learned a lot out information technology. Gained social skills interacting with staff. Learned about numerous software and hardware troubleshooting methods.
cons: The technology help desk was understaffed and underfunded. We were in charge of way too many clients. A lot of tasks were boring and tedious.

pros: Resources for conducting research, including shared facilities; Opportunities for collaboration; Easy public transit access; School of engineering facilities; Advocacy group for postdocs and graduate students
cons: Some personnel are lacking; Lack of integration of postdocs into the department culture; Fitness facilities for postdocs, faculty, and staff are outdated and are not centrally located

pros: Working as a undergraduate researcher at Pitt is a low-stress job with decent compensation. Depending on the lab you are in, you could be given a fair amount of agency when it comes to working on projects, but your mileage may vary.
cons: Pitt does not have the most advanced paperwork services so that can be a hassle at times. The overall pace of student research can be slow and underwhelming at times.

review_title: Good health insurance, Good medical research environment. Staff could be low efficient sometime
pros:
Pitt provides very good health insurance. I know people transferred from other places to Pitt because they need a better insurance. 
There are very active neuroscience and neural disease research programs.
cons:
Pay for staff is not high. 
Sometime, some staff may not be very efficient or not happy with what they are doing.

pros: The University of Pittsburgh does a great job to ensure that the men's and women's basketball programs receive the same perks.  The coaches offices, player's locker rooms, and video rooms are mirror images.  They truly abided by the rule that what's good for one gender is just as good for the other.
cons: The University of Pittsburgh athletic leadership did not display the best leadership for sports other than football and men's basketball.

job_title: Systems Programmer IV in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The benefits and perks are outstanding. Great co-workers and flexible management. High level of job satisfaction, real sense of making an impact.
cons: Pay is lower than that comparable corporate position, but that is somewhat made up for with the benefits. Not a lot of room for advancement unless entering as a lower level position.

pros: Undergrad tuition benefit for dependents - only if they attend Pitt
cons:
A winner-take-all non-collaborative work environment where you are left to fend for yourself and compete against your colleagues.
Benefits are poor (except for tuition) for faculty - very high medical/dental insurance and co-pays; no carry-over of sick leave or vacation, so that when you leave Pitt you don't get paid anything for your accumulated leave. This is unlike state universities.
Low faculty pay. 
Horrible parking.
Poor administrative support
Retirement does not compare to many state universities - you get only 1:1 match and are not vested for first 3 years.

pros:
- Good Salary
- Good Benefit
- Good leaning resources such as Lynda.com, Safari Book Online or Box.
cons: I am a software developer in the department, which its main function is not relate to any software development at all. It kinds of hard to have a knowledgeable coworkers or good career mentors. I used to work in the software company. Then, we all have to learning and sharing our knowledge between us. This is totally difference.

pros: Great environment, safe city, facilities for student and faculties.
cons: I think they should care more about the silent harassment that is happening every day in different places and many people like me are scared to report it because of our job security.

review_title: Overall, a good place to work
pros:
- great benefits
- great work/life balance
- tuition discounts are excellent
cons:
- LOTS of red tape and bureaucracy
- lack of diversity within senior management in all departments
- lower wages compared to other colleges
- employees are very focused on their specific areas and not on the University as a whole

review_title: Great place to work, but my office needs supervision.
pros:
Campus environment & accessibility
Access to education and services
Free public transportation
Great PTO benefits
Stable job
cons: My office does not receive appropriate supervision and workers suffer because of it. An example of this is that te office administrator hires her friends, has favorites, and does not enforce the same rules for everyone.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: This might be specific to my department but I enjoyed working with supportive staff and faculty. there was a great deal of flexibility to revise one's schedule to fit classes and other meetings in. Excellent leadership and team work !
cons: Work could get really busy or dull depending on how the research study was progressing. Also, there could be a lot of turnover in terms of staff depending on budget changes.

pros: Research is good and a great learning experience. Pitt has a wide range of  biomedical research disciplines and experts, which make it a great institution to learn and apply for grants.
cons: The biggest challenge is the biotechnology and pharmaceutical companies are not strongly present in Pittsburgh, which make it more challenging to transfer the basic research. However, Pitt is really pushing hard to change that.

review_title: It doesn't matter if you work hard or hardly work
job_title: Research Specialist IV in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: They provide excellent benefits such as riding public transportation for free, and taking undergraduate and graduate classes for next to no cost.
cons: Once you are hired at a certain salary, it is impossible to make money. People hired off the street can get hired with a lesser title and a greater salary, but they will not let you get more than a 3% raise.

pros: Able to get homework done most of the time (huge for a student), friendly staff and co-workers, most student jobs are relatively easy
cons: minimum wage pay, can only work 20 hours per week (state requirement)

review_title: One of the best places to work in Pittsburgh
pros: Amazing benefits and time off, respectable organization, many opportunities for personal and career growth, beautiful location, annual salary increases
cons: Hiring process is very slow. It's also very bureaucratic, but that's to be expected at a university. For example, a coworker had a hard time submitting documentation for why they were out sick for a few days. You have to pay attention to all the rules.

review_title: Overall, a good place to work and gain experience.
job_title: Summer Buildings Manager in Bradford, PA
pros:
flexible time off
candid feedback from supervisors
great on campus enviroment to work at
clear objectives
available tools needed to complete tasks
cons:
Located in a very poor and depressing town with little to do
poor compensation for difficult work
overtime is required yet uncompensated for

pros: good place to work with empowerment. Intellectual challenge,  good profs and research facilities. Folks are able to carve out their growth plan.
cons: Low salary and long hours beyond this it is a fine place to be. One gets to learn and grow.

review_title: Nice place to work if you don't need to eat.
pros: Tuition assistance for self and children, winter break, well known name, great work schedule.  Really enjoyed the people that I worked with and the students.
cons: Horribly low salaries!!  Benefits were very expensive.  Cost of monthly parking passes were too high.  Complacent, lazy managers.  There was absolutely no training for a position that dealt with very time sensitive material.

review_title: Pitt is a great place to work!!
pros: Pitt is a great place to work because the benefits are excellent and you know at the end of the day that you are helping students learn.
cons: Unfortunately, Pitt is very much a bureaucracy. In many ways, it seems to function like a much larger company than it is. This can lead to a certain level of inefficiency when trying to accomplish tasks.

review_title: Good student employment at Student Computing Services.
pros: SCS usually can get you hours that fit into your schedule and you will get raises even though you start at minimum wage. I started my Sophomore year and I was making over $9 an hour by my senior year.
cons: Work can sometimes be dull and frustrating, especially when you have to answer the same question or do the same service for many customers.

pros: Higher than minimum wage, great boss (Rhett Kennedy), easy position, work-study program (can do homework on the job)
cons: limited hours based on co-workers and current class schedule, must be a student to be hired, other than that no cons, terrific position and resume builder

review_title: Don't expect help from HR if you complain about racial discrimination and harassment. They will cover it up.
job_title: Systems Programmer IV in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Work here so you can get the tuition and health benefits. Then leave.
cons: They hire stupid people that are their friends and relatives. If you are good at your job, watch out, they will try to find some fault with you and marginalize you. The facilities suck as well. A lot of the buildings are converted labs and storage rooms, so expect to freeze or bake, with no end in sight.

pros: Pitt offered a good way for students in my field to gain experience related to my field by working directly for the university. Our hours were quite flexible and we were compensated for prep time.
cons: The wage was fairly low considering the level of knowledge needed to perform duties. Moreover, there was no real channel to improve wage/work under better conditions. Not many incentives to stand out.

pros: The opportunity for Continuing education is good. The faculty are smart and the options for study are broad. And the students on campus are smart. Still trying to fill in 20 word min.
cons: No opportunity unless you are in circles, generally closed minded to those from corporate.  They spend hours coaching themselves and little experience on real world execution.

review_title: Great place to launch a career.
pros: The University of Pittsburgh allows for a great balance between work and life. Being on a college campus is great.
cons: The salary is not as competitive as i would like, but that is expected. Other than that there is nothing to complain about.

review_title: pretty okay place in which to work
pros: Good place to find employment, great benefits.
cons: Outdated computer system (my.pitt.edu) that is really a labyrinth of ridiculous links and poorly designed web portals.  Several layers of bureaucracy for every move you make.

review_title: Dynamic experience with respect to research and courses at University of Pittsburgh
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
Nice work culture, diversity, friendly and collaborative people at the Engineering and Medical schools at University of Pittsburgh. 
Also, a nice city to stay in with friendly neighborhoods.
cons: Career fair for graduates not up to the mark. More incentives need to be taken to lure companies in picking students at the graduate level with extensive experience in Engineering.

pros:
- Good benefits and great co-workers
- I truly loved my job. At the time I worked there, they were a best in class purchasing organization, and it was great to be on the ground floor of building that organization.
- Our senior leader was fantastic.
cons: - The training for new and existing managers was almost non-existent, so that could be improved.

review_title: Student research assistant in industrial engineering, close cooperation with industry
pros: I worked as a research assistant in masters program, involved in a research project associated with b-school. The professors in our department is nice. Weekly meeting, sometimes with industrial professions.
cons: I got some trouble when getting in the employment, the administration systems seems buggy.

review_title: It was a good experience. I wouldn't have continued or taken this job if I had any better option.
pros: The PI that I worked with was very supportive and provided me flexibility to work any time during the day and anytime during the week.
cons: It was very underpaid job compared to the research skills and effort it required.

review_title: If you want a cushy job, this is the place for you
pros: Work hours are flexible, turnover is low so people know each other like family.
cons: Change is slow to come and people don't like doing things differently. If you have a lot of energy and want to change the world, this is not the place for you.

review_title: A lot of freedom, not that much structure
pros: Great benefits, lots of freedom with what you want to teach, decent community between professors/adjuncts
cons: Not a whole lot of structure, expect to learn on the fly and ask your coworkers questions about how every process works. No real onboarding process.

job_title: Retail Sales Associate in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Very fun and family-like atmosphere. Even being a student employee, you get input on upcoming season's apparel. Meeting and helping new people/students is always super fun. They are flexible with exam and class schedules as well as time off. It was one of my favorite jobs in college.
cons: I can't think of anything!

job_title: Graduate Student Scholar in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: the library system is good. The living expense is not high. Faculty and staff members have some benefits e.g. education benefits.
cons: I am working in the IT fields and in this area, Pitt has obviously incompetence compared with its neighboring university, CMU.

review_title: University review for university of Pittsburgh
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: I am a graduate student in this university. Its in a very nice city, and graduate students get very good benefits. The reach facility is also very good.
cons: i feel this university is developing sorta slow. For example, in my department, new faculties dont really bring new and creative stuff.

job_title: Systems Programmer III in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great benefits(tuition, health, retirement), campus atmosphere, relaxed work environment, winter recess, vacation and sick time.
cons: Very difficult to increase your salary once you work at Pitt, if you stay too long (5+ years) your salary will be less than new hires. You would need to leave Pitt and come back to get a decent salary, thus losing all the benefits you've earned from working there...

pros:
Great benefits
Ability to meet and work with a diverse population
cons: POLITICS! Administration has an idea of the image they want projected through their staff members, and if you do not fit into that, well you are out of luck.  Student life by nature has weird hours, but there is no additional benefit to make up for them such as flexible schedules.

review_title: Good place to study and work
pros:
Able to do research with relatively renowned professors
Able to balance research schedule with class schedule
Good school prestige when looking for future employers
cons:
The hourly wages for a student research assistant are moderate.
As a student research assistant you are unlikely to have many coworkers.
Some tasks that you are assigned as a student research assistant are a bit menial.

review_title: Good research, average career development for students
pros: Good academic community: collaboration with Carnegie Mellon University and the UPMC hospitals. Research facilities are modern and faculty are generally approachable.
cons: Like most Universities, it's hit or miss about career development depending on the principal investigator you work for. No oversight or accountability by Departments or graduate student organizations, although a graduate student union is forming, with strong dissent from the university

review_title: Great way to develop IT skills in a pretty stress free environment and, being a student, the payment is wonderful.
pros: The payment comes in the form of a stipend paying for room and board.
cons: Communication is weak but it is a result of being part of a huge company.

pros: It's a great location! The school has excellent academics and virtually any club you could want to join. Classes can be really difficult though, so study hard.
cons: A bit crowded on the streets. Choose your major carefully so that you don't have to switch it and then go longer than four years. Make sure to get sleep before exams.

review_title: It's good. It's really depends on your boss.
pros: Since I'm working in academia, the work time is flexible. It doesn't have to be 9am-5pm. You have the chance to work with world well known researchers.
cons: The winter is super cold. The salary is low, because my title is Post-doc fellow. It's really competitive, so it's hard to get promoted unless you are really good.

review_title: As both a student-employee and non-student employee, I had a very good experience and was always able to learn.
pros: Great access to lots of the similar services (city and university) as students and very good work hours.
cons: Pay isn't always the highest and many departments are subject to various government grants and stringent operating budgets.

job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great people, good environment, progressive thinking and a mission to do good things
cons: There is a lot of great work being done and many transformational projects underway.  It will help to pace these things to ensure a good work-life balance for employees

pros: The people are very friendly and willing to help. Also the university offers a lot of resources for the employee's benefit.
cons: As with any large university there can be a lot of hoops to jump through when you are first being hired.

review_title: Decent working environment and benefits, but low pay
pros: The campus is lovely. The benefits are quite good and it is generally a good place to work. Pittsburgh is also a cheap city.
cons: They expect you to pay for parking - at least $90 a month. The pay is notoriously low - so normally these jobs are out of a 'labor of love'. The bureaucracy is an absolute nightmare.

pros: The University has amazing benefits and a stellar retirement policy.
cons: None about the University as a whole.

pros: Nothing entirely unexpected here.  The fun of being in an engage classroom almost outweighs the tedium of departmental meetings.
cons: Eeeeveryone feels the need to had themselves speak at meetings, and so everything takes 200% longer than it should.  I once served on a committee that took 11 months to alter a three page document that detailed exam requirements.

pros: they real care about the satisfaction of all of their employees, no matter the position or rank they hold
cons: i can't name a single con about the university of pittsburgh, other than the price to be here every single day

review_title: Great place for Growth and Development
pros: If you work in a unit or as part of committees that are dedicated to the growth and development of their employees, Pitt is a great place to gain the soft and hard skills necessary to further your career.
cons: As with most higher education institutions, bureaucracy can make it difficult to push new ideas forward and begin new initiatives.

pros: Work environment is positive and all students, graduate and undergraduate are treated fairly and positively by the large majority of professors. I haven't had a bad experience in my time there.
cons: Not really any, pay can always be more but its definitely unfair.

pros: In my tenure at Pitt, the upper administration has been incredibly supportive. There is a decent amount of institutional funding available for research and department initiatives.
cons: Relative to other institutions of similar size, the salary (at least within the Fine Arts) is not very competitive.

review_title: Not intense, but you need to make progress every week
pros:
Communicate with client once a week to figure out the need.
Not so push. but need progress every week
Clients are very accessible.
cons:
Not so challenging.
No teamwork. Work alone all the time, if you have a bug or problem, you have nobody to talk to.

job_title: Research Assistant III in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
Education benefits including graduate school
Great health care from UPMC
Flexible schedule. Great vacation benefits and most holidays
Child care
Free public transit from Port Authority
cons:
Lower pay than most other employers for similar jobs.
Very poor leadership depending on which school and department you are in.
Very hard to use education benefits because online class options limited and most classes during workday.

pros: Good pay, set my own hours, worked under a really great professor. Would definitely recommend the job to any qualified student.
cons: There were not any notable cons. If anything, there was almost too little oversight over the position.

pros: Facilities and breadth of research represented by faculty.
cons: Lack of consistent institutional policies esp on professional development and promotion (e.g. tenure review, annual reviews); opaque & changing criteria on academic promotions -- 20-30% reductions in salaries determined solely by dept. heads with no real review.  General absence of oversight of those holding leadership positions and influence of faculty body particularly low. Problems reflect dissolution of academic standards, unveiled favoritism blatantly practiced in the medical school and absence of "checks & balances" with power concentrated at higher administrative levels. Untenured faculty esp at risk.

pros: I have been a part-time worker at Sodexo. I have learnt how to help people with their troubles albeit in a smaller way and enjoyed serving people and give them the best service from us.
cons: It was a little strenous physically at the start to work for 8 hours with just a single break but have gotten used to it now.

pros: the city is great and not expensive. A student stipend can afford you a decent living. Rent in nice areas can be as low as $600/mo if you have a roommate.
cons: The school spirit is nothing compared to schools located in smaller cities. When it comes to sports the city is moved by Pgh sports teams and Pitt is pretty secondary.

pros:
* The position I had was very flexible
*  Only allowed to work a certain amount of hours so you won't be overworked
* Aware of finals schedule so no conflicts
cons:
* Pay isn't great but fine for a student 
* Can only work a certain amount of hours so if you are looking for more work don't do work study.

pros: Decent salary. 2 weeks off at Christmas.  Nice environment
cons: Every woman for themselves.  Poor support. Poor communication.

review_title: Not a great place to work
job_title: Corporate and Foundation Relations Manager in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The faculty are world class and doing amazing, life-saving research.
cons: The leadership ruled by fear and kept employees in the dark about  major decisions or factors that affected them. No raises, no morale-boosters. They nickel and dimed you on vacation time (which is sparse as it is). The pay disparity between most of the employees and the top leadership was just incredible ($50K a year vs $500K a year).

pros: Well rewarded for hard work creativity and good teaching
cons: Parking is a nightmare, top administrators are obsessed with diversity over anything else even excellence in education and research

pros: Slow most of the time, office was pretty calm.  It was just enough work that a doctor wouldn't need to do it themselves.  Most of the time I could just do homework.
cons: Was sometimes offered as a "scalp" to other departments, and had to do random non-office related tasks. Like cleaning a kitchen? It was never that bad though.

pros: Flexible hours, decent pay, manageable workload. My son is able to attend the university for free simply from me working there.
cons: Very little vacation time (compared to other universities). There is not much room for promotion within the administrative assistant field.

pros:
Benefits are excellent steady work  
exposed to new technolgy
cons:
24/7 environment under staffed 
the reason I gave 3 stars in over all rating is just for the department I'm in 
this dose not represent the university as a whole most of the staff has been there 10+
and other departments have a better environment

pros: Mostly nice people across the university. Some of the buildings are phenomenal. Accessible for most East End, Oakland, Downtown residents.
cons: Parking is hard to come by, and very very expensive. The department for which I teach is disorganized and overworks all adjuncts, graduate students, and PhD's, even going so far as to change the definition of credits per person for workload.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great health benefits, free bus passes make the city fully accessible, free access to many of the city's museums during the spring and fall semesters.
cons: Campus is a high traffic area, many of the surrounding housing areas are not well maintained (they are covered in garbage and broken glass), there is a huge drinking culture amongst the undergraduate students.

pros: The University of Pittsburgh is a place that gives back a lot. The have growth in employment opportunities. The staff members are generous, caring and willing to lend a helping hand.
cons: At times you might have an issue with co-workers. The hiring process is really complicated.

pros: Good Benefits, laid back environment, friendly people. Depends on the office you work in, but flexible schedule.
cons: the salaries are typically low

pros: Pitt offers great health benefits, vacation, and paid time off (but you must take it!).  Choose a PI with a good funding history and can support you for a few years.
cons: The research funding is so tight right now, that PIs are willing to sacrifice funding for talented postdocs.  Not a good time to be in academic research.

pros:
Excellent, high level science
Cutting-edge equipment
Interesting and friendly people
Cosmopolitan, open-minded environment
cons: The salary for postdoctoral scholars is rather on the low end of the scale. Upper management was not convincing in their handling of  the series of bomb threats in 2012. They only ended once the perpetrators decided to stop sending threats, not because of any decisive action by the university.

review_title: too much stress to find a grant for the boss
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: there are good profs to work with. The quality of research  is high. You can have good collaborations with scientists with different background.
cons: There is a lot of pressure for finding grants at School of Medicine. Even tenured prof.s had to close their lab due to lack of grants.

review_title: Great place to study, work and live.
pros: Diversity, academics are challenging, great networking opportunities in the city, great sports facilities, relatively safe city environment, party culture fun but not overwhelming.
cons: Outdated facilities and residence halls, difficulty transferring credits, disconnect between college of arts and sciences and college of business administration

pros: Good environment for researches. The faculties are very enthusiastic about their own research projects and they are very nice to students. The traffic is very good and you can basically go to everywhere you want in this urban city.
cons: The winter is long, and the sunny days in a year is limited. Sometimes, this weather will affect the working mood.

review_title: Good if you want the academic life
job_title: Systems Programmer IV in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
- Nice Campus
- Salary depends on who (or which PI) you work for - can be good or bad
- Flexible work hours
cons:
- Bureaucratic: not a good thing if you are trying to do both research and work
- Forget about career growth unless you jump from one department to another

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Millburn, NJ
pros: I worked as a work-study student. The staff are very friendly and the processes are easy to follow. Great experience overall!
cons: Finding a work-study position at first is a bit time consuming considering how many students applied for each job. Sometimes it is a bit hard to find the right time slot.

review_title: Good place to work, especially if you have a family
pros:
Great benefits in health care, amenities, and education
Good pay
Free public transportation
Access to many university resources
Discounted memberships and items throughout the community
cons:
Differing work hours (can require you to work extra days without notice)
Healthcare benefits only good at UMPC facilities (though that is both a pro and a con)

review_title: great place to live and work
pros: Nice people, nice working environement. If you are a big fan of STEELERS, come here. Not too much pressure for life. Decent salary.
cons: If you don't like cold weather, Pittsburgh is probably not your choice. Life is relatively steady in university, so it may be a little hard for you to get promoted.

review_title: Lots of great professors and research opportunities
pros: Pitt has a great career services department as well as a job/internhship search site specifically for students. I found three great positions during my time there- not top of the line pay for student worker positions but they have opened up lots of networking and career opportunities.
cons: Hourly wages aren't the best thing.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The University of Pittsburgh post-doc association is great at providing support and benefits to postdocs at the University.  Further, the extensive research community at UP and surrounding areas is superb.
cons: Working in a lab off campus can be somewhat inconvenient at times as the main university is a 15-20 minute shuttle ride away.

review_title: Good place to work if you are going back to school
pros: They help pay for school and you are out early by 4:30-5:00 everyday.
cons: The salary is horrendous and is only worth it if you are going to go to school, in which they will help you pay for a huge chunk of it

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: I'm a Ph.D. student at Pitt, and previously worked there as staff for 2.5 years. Pitt has good benefits, in terms of health and education, and is fairly stable. For a University, it is relatively non-toxic, at least in Psychology where I am.
cons: It is a University, so there is lots of bureaucracy, and the pay sucks.

pros: Great benefits, including good retirement match, paid time off, ample sick time.  Great work life balance and friendly work environment.  Access to fitness areas, tuition reimbursement, and good health insurance, too.
cons: Parking can be difficult to obtain, although you get a free bus pass.

review_title: Good work environment except for one major flaw
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Friendly co-workers, great city with lots to do, work-life balance is feasible
cons: Multiple reports of harassment and retaliation have been swept under the rug in efforts to protect tenured faculty or save face from public scrutiny.

job_title: Systems Analyst IV in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great benefits.  Ample time off.  Good retirement.
cons: IF you are already a highly experienced employee, there many be little opportunity for advancement.  It depends on what department you are in.  In my department, annual raises amount to nothing more than cost of living raises even if you are doing a super job.

pros: Great benefits, supervisor is invested in my professional development, interesting work and pleasant colleagues.
cons: There are so many benefits (like software, gyms, etc) that it can be hard to take advantage of what is there.

job_title: Student Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Swanson School at University of Pittsburgh is a very good place for engineer. There are advanced equipment, good lab environment. Professors are kind and insightful. One can get very well research experience at University of Pittsburgh.
cons: There is no cons I would add.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: get to create your own hours as a student worker and they are really flexible when it comes time for mid terms and final examinations.
cons: you get paid once a month, no matter who you are. you can be the dean or a janitor. you get paid once a month.

job_title: Assistant Strength Coach in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great fringe benefits from the university. We get a phone that is paid for, 4 to 5 pairs of shoes a year. Also lots and lots of gear from nike.
cons: Minimal payment for the level of work that we do. Also very little support from our administration is given to the su port staff.

review_title: this was one of the best companies I have ever worked for
pros: The pros of this University was seeing the students smile as I served them there meals for the day as well as the benefit plans.
cons: The downside of this company was when they were on break there wasn't any hours available

pros: Salary is not bad and the workload is fair as a TA. The working environment is a great, and it is a good opportunity for me to get a deeper understanding of the course I was taught.
cons: The work load is terriblly heavy if assisting a professor with a terrible grading policy.

pros: It has been rewarding affording one the opportunities to take initiatives  and creative in problems solving at management level. The exposure to new ideas to solving problems in social sciences and management capabilities.
cons: It is limited to research and management minimal exposure to the private sector.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great learning experience to teach other people.  I would recommend to gain the value experience of teaching others in your field.
cons:
Average pay - 10$/hr
There weren't many cons.  Just a lot of work to do for 10$/hr is all.

pros: Great people, amazing benefits, opportunities for professional development
cons: Extremely low pay, regardless of education and previous work experience

job_title: Computer Lab Monitor in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Easy work, generally flexible hours to your schedule, and can often do homework while working.
cons: Dealing with customers can be frustrating when they are angry or unreasonable, but this is rare. Sometimes the work also gets tedious and coworkers may not pull their weight.

pros: good people, good community, solid benefits
cons: admin bogs everything down, not flexible and no raises

job_title: Academic Records Coordinator in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Many opportunities for work; good transportation, free bus pass

review_title: CSSD is a meat grinder for managers

review_title: great place to work and study
pros:
great city, great graduate school, and everyone around is quite helpful
students were quite motivated
free bus pass

no insurance to part-time students. 
does not really pay much
need to hold office hours really early in the morning

pros: My boss was flexible with me and the whole office I worked in was welcoming and willing to help.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Pittsburgh, PA

review_title: Great place to go to graduate school
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Pittsburgh, PA

cons: No Cons to report right now

Laidback environment

Opportunities to advance

review_title: I had the most wonderful experience there

pros: Comparatively large amount of paid time off,  free access to public transit, and great employer match on retirement savings.

review_title: Good benefits, great colleagues, greater good

pros: The benefits are excellent. Accrual a lot of time off. 401K with company match. Education assistance. People that work here are generally good as well.

review_title: Good atmosphere and spirit in University setting, very heavily regulated actions from top down.

pros: Large university with lots of funding opportunities for rising faculty.  New Chancellor doing good work.

pros: This position at university of Pittsburgh has a lot of benefits apart from the fact that is decently paid. Every Ta also receives Insurance benefits from UPMC.

pros: The University is a wonderful employer! I have been an employee for almost 20 years. The work has been stimulating and you can't beat the benefits it offers.

review_title: Just what you'd expect from a research focused academic institution

pros: Educational benefits for family.  Retirement benefits.  Free pass to ride PAT to and from work.

review_title: OK, not much chance for advancement , always favorites

review_title: In this current economy where people getting fired all the time - this has me the peace of mind

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Pittsburgh, PA

The University of Pittsburgh is an excellent environment for a graduate student. It has all support and infrastructure that one might need. The faculty is supportive and knowledgeable. 
Excellent health benefits. Public transportation is free for students.
cons: As any academic environment there is more bureaucracy than I would like.

pros: The wonderful thing of working here is the flexible work time. Also, the benefits from the university if very good.

pros: Excellent benefits, home/work life balance, individual input is valued, get to work with latest technology, competitive compensation.  Training on latest technology is offered as well as learning materials.  Great senior management team.

pros: Salary is only average, but tuition benefits are outstanding, and the other benefits are also very good.

pros: My department was the best.  Very nice staff.  I was promoted and had good salary increase.

review_title: Great place to learn and collaborate with people from multiple fields

review_title: Fantastic. Great for UTAs, peer tutors, and help desk employees.

pros: The department I worked in was really supportive and flexible with my schedule since I was also a student there.

review_title: A good place to for student workers
